Good morning, Raider Nation!

Not the way we anticipated the first day of school, but we will work to make the most of this for our Raiders.

This remote learning will be vastly different. We believe it is vitally important for teachers to have instructional time with students. That is why we are having school from 8-11:30 just as if we were in the building.

Students are to log in and be in the virtual classroom at their scheduled class time. Students are in school each day.

We are all in this together. We will have items come up that will not work today. If we stay in communication, we can overcome all of the obstacles, allowing teachers and students to be together on this path of education.

Be patient as we test this full scale today. We have conducted small-scale tests, but nothing at this level.

Have a great first day, Raider Nation!

And, with graduation on Friday, the final Senior Spotlight for the Class of 2020!

Steven Nichols is the son of Jason and Barb Hazlet and Louie and Claire Nichols.

Steven found out years ago he was interested in attacking a career involving automobiles. His passion for engines and vehicles leads him to attend a trade school for auto mechanics.

We are proud of Steven for putting together the finishing touches on his senior year to reach his diploma and move forward in his career. With his passion for auto mechanics, he will complete the work necessary to succeed in that essential field.

Congrats, Steven!

Mrs. Kerby and husband Travis have two children and reside in the Central A&M School District.

Olivia is going into 6th grade and Georgia is starting kindergarten this year.

Welcome home, Mrs. Kerby!

shared_text:
Nicole Ekiss
June 19 at 6:57 AM 路

Happy Juneteenth!
Juneteenth is a celebration commemorating the ending of slavery in the United States. On June 19, 1865, Major General Gordon Granger, along with Union troops, arrived in Galveston, Texas with news of Lincolns Emancipation Proclamation that had taken effect on January 1, 1863. Prior to this, there was no Union presence in Texas and Lincolns Proclamation was not being enforced. Although today marks a substantial win for freedom and justice in the United States, there is still much work to be done to address the inequitable and biased systems dating back to our countrys origins.

A first for Raider Nation!

Congratulations to Sarah Berg, who earned Central A&M's first ever Seal of Biliteracy!

From Spanish Teacher Mr. Jess Lehman:

Join me in congratulating Sarah Berg on earning the Illinois State Seal of Biliteracy in English and Spanish. The State Seal of Biliteracy program recognizes high school graduates who have attained a high level of proficiency in English and in one or more foreign languages. This bilingual stamp of approval allows colleges, universities, and employers to distinguish between students who say they know a second language and those who can actually prove their abilities. Sarah is the first CAM student to earn the Seal since the adoption of the program in 2018.

Way to go, Sarah!

Early morning walk....early morning thoughts.

The Veterans Monument is my favorite place on my walk. Quiet and peaceful, but it also stands for the freedom after the storm.

With the sun behind, the flag takes on a sunny hue. Standing in between the flag and the sun, I see the red, white, and blue shine.

The brave listed on these stones inspire me to think of those who are stepping up during this time.

Thank God for the people sacrificing to meet the health, financial, emotional, and other necessities of those in need. You will help us all share the freedom after this storm.

Thinking of all of you today.

post_text:
Pushed to tears tonight as the Central A&M Raiders fall in the IHSA SuperSectional in Carbondale.

The loss hurts...but it is more than that. It is the realization that this group will not play together again. Sure, they are blessed with talent. However, they are blessed with work ethic. They gave us so many thrills the past few years.

And, this hurt is for the whole team. The Seniors are crushed as one would expect, but the freshmen, sophomores and juniors feel it, too. They are now charged to carry this momentum forward and make it a tradition. But, tonight, they ache for the seniors.

We in Raider Nation are also proud of the athletes as they gave all they had and came up short, as most teams do.

All this breaks my heart as a principal who cares about these kids.

And it even goes deeper than that.

I will miss them as athletes....but that does not compare to how I will miss them as people....as I feel each and every May when the next set of seniors graduates.

Thanks for the ride, Raiders!

A splendid evening of music as 9 Band Raiders joined musicians from 8 other area high schools at the Area Honor Band Concert tonight in Morrisonville.

The talented students spent the day in Morrisonville learning from Dr. Phillip Hash from Illinois State University. Dr. Hash then conducted the concert, which included the following selections:

Brighton Beach March (William Latham)
Anthem for Winds and Percussion (C.T. Smith)
Jupiter Hymn (Gustav Holst arr. J. De Meij)
Three Chinese Miniatures (Robert Jager)
Avengers: Endgame (arr. Michael Brown)

We are proud of Central A&M Director Matt Parker and musicians Nick Collins (clarinet), Madison Warnick (flute), Kaylee Lawrence (flute), Isaac Nidiffer (saxophone), Aden Sanders (baritone sax), Alice Jackson (trumpet), Joe Rund (trombone), and Christina Myers (euphonium).

A wonderful night of music!

Hannah has been very involved at Central A&M. She is a consistent member of the Honor Roll. She has participated in basketball, cheerleading, softball, Mentor Leadership, football manager, and Science Club. She enjoys spending time in Mrs. Hardimon's class as a Teacher's Aide.

We are very proud of Hannah and look forward to her future in medicine.

Congrats, Hannah!
